If only President Obama possess a resume like this:
Benjamin Netanyahu was born in 1949 in Tel Aviv, and grew up in Jerusalem. During his high school years, his family moved to the United States, where his father Dr. Ben-Zion Netanyahu was offered an academic post.

Upon his return to Israel in 1967, he was drafted to the Israeli Army, and served 5 years in the elite Sayeret Maktal unit. He took part in several military operations, including the famed hostage rescue aboard the hijacked "Sabena" flight in 1972. During the same year he received a decoration for command of an operation from the late IDF chief-of-staff Motta Gur. He participated in the Yom Kippur war as a reserve officer and was promoted to the rank of captain.
... See More... See More... See More
Following his army service, Netanyahu enrolled at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he matriculated with a BS in Architecture. He remained at MIT for his graduate studies where he earned an MBA from the Sloan School of Management. As a student, he also pursued studies in political science both at MIT and at neighboring Harvard.

Between 1976-1982, Netanyahu worked in the private sector, for the Boston Consulting Group, and later as a member of senior management for RIM Industries Ltd.

Both in 1979 and 1984, Netanyahu organized international conferences on anti-terrorism, which emphasized the need to oppose terror organizations and the regimes that supported them. Former U.S. Secretary of State George Schultz wrote that Netanyahu's public activism and authorship of books on terrorism had a profound effect on the formation of American foreign policy in response to international terrorism.

Netanyahu was appointed Deputy Chief of Mission at the Israeli Embassy in Washington, D.C. In 1982. In 1984 he was appointed the Israeli Ambassador to the United Nations, where he served for four years. During this period, he was known for his determined and tenacious support of the Israeli effort to influence international public opinion. He successfully led an effort to permit public access to the UN Nazi war criminals archive, which up to that time had been classified.

Upon his return to Israel in 1988, Netanyahu was elected to the Knesset as a Likud MK, and served as Deputy Foreign Minister. During the 1991 Gulf War, Mr. Netanyahu was a prominent representative of Israel in the international arena. Later that year, he was a senior member of the Israeli delegation to the Madrid peace conference. He was also a member of the first American-Israeli Committee for Strategic Cooperation.

In 1993, Netanyahu was elected to lead the Likud party, replacing former Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, and to serve as Leader of the Opposition. In 1996, he was elected Prime Minister of Israel.

During his tenure as Prime Minister, Netanyahu pursued a firm policy against terror, while working to propel the peace process. He and his government worked hard to reach balanced agreements with the Palestinians based on the principle of Reciprocity. By the end of his 3-year term, the level of terrorism in Israel had declined drastically.

On the economic front, Netanyahu liberalized the foreign-currency exchange, accelerated the privatization of government-held companies, and reduced the deficit. During his time in office, foreign investment in the Israeli High-Tech industry reached record levels of billions of dollars a year.

After leaving office in 1999, Netanyahu served as a consultant for Israeli High-Tech companies. He was a highly sought-after speaker in various forums around the world and maintained a rigorous lecturing schedule.

Netanyahu returned to public life in 2002 first as Foreign Minister and in 2003 as Finance Minister in the Sharon Government. In this position, he encouraged growth by reducing the public sector and strengthening private enterprise. His policy included reducing government spending, lowering taxes, limiting government handouts, and eliminating monopolies, renewing privatization and pension reform. The U.S. Government as well as international financial institutions such as credit rating companies and the IMF lauded these actions. As a result, the decline in the Israeli economy was reversed, unemployment was reduced, and growth restored. The Israeli economy, having shrunk by 1% in the years 2001 and 2002, grew by 4.2% in 2004.

Netanyahu has authored a number of books that have been published in Hebrew, English, and at times also Russian, French, Arabic, Japanese, and other languages:

- "Letters to Yoni" (1978) editor and co-author with his brother Iddo

- "International Terrorism: Challenge and Response" (1979), editor

- "Terrorism: How the West Can Win" (1987), editor

- "A Place Among the Nations" (1993)

- "Fighting Terrorism: How Democracies Can Defeat Domestic And International Terrorism" (1995)

Benjamin Netanyahu is married to Sarah, a psychologist by profession, now working in the Jerusalem Psychological Services.

Mr. Netanyahu has 3 children. The Netanyahu family resides in Jerusalem.

 Speech by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Council on Foreign Relations, etc. Tamuz Golden Age, 8 July 2010

Thank you all that you gave me the opportunity to talk with you about the pressing issues at hand. I am very pleased that distinguished delegation with me today - Ambassador Michael Oren, Ambassador Gabriela Shalev, Assaf Shariv consul my entourage, Dr. Uzi Arad Ron Dremar. Thanks to everyone who is here today.

We got a very good day in Washington. I said in the Oval Office on Pttiratm reports of the special relationship between the United States and Israel are not only early, but they are not true. The reports are not true not only for the undisputed relationship between our two countries. This relationship is anchored in shared values, democracy is among the top values we shared. But the relationship is anchored in the common interests - this is about increasing the differences that may cost between our two governments from time to time. The reports are not true because last year most of the disputes focused on how to advance the peace process and the question of whether to advance the process. Sometimes we do not agree about how to resume the peace process but we also share the strong desire to do so as soon as possible.

So I believe that President Obama and I agree on how to proceed now, how to pass close calls for direct talks and how to ensure that these direct talks would be with content that they will resume soon. This delay does not help us. In my opinion, delay the process - the talk about whether to speak conditioning conditions to start talking - big mistake. We spent a year and I do not think we should waste any more time.

Both sides is wrong. We have also done an injustice. For example, public squares and the Palestinians pay the names of terrorists, including the last terrorist. I could say: "Well, until you change the name of these squares, do not start conversations." It will cost us in time. I think the right thing to do is move to direct talks as soon as possible. This is the only way to solve this conflict, and he needs to solve.

Essence of peace is a two-state solution with demilitarized Palestinian state that recognizes the Jewish state, Israel. This vision is anchored on two principles - security and legitimacy. Sound security principle of course - talking about security for some time but you have to understand the security challenge has changed. Since the Oslo talks, when we opened peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians, there were two changes. The first is the rise of Iran and its branches and the other is the rise of warfare with missiles and rockets.

Both these developments are a significant problem for Israel. Asking us to prepare our citizens for the evacuation of areas such peace. After all, we did it twice already. The first time was in Lebanon and Iranian branches quickly took control of areas evacuated and began to smuggle large quantities of rockets and missiles into these areas - rockets and missiles fired at us later.

The second time was in the Gaza Strip. We evacuated the Gaza Strip until the last centimeter. This space is quickly taken over Iran's branches. Missiles and rockets are injected into these areas and fired them at Israel - 12,000 rockets and missiles is just a small area if - what New - Jersey. Think about it - this is a serious problem.

If a third evacuation, we must answer the question how to prevent such a situation might happen a third time. One bounce, two bounce, bounce third and you "outside". In Israel's case, it is a real strategic threat because they target Israeli towns, our airports are the target of our military installations are a target. We need to find a real solution to this problem, not just on paper but a solution to a real solution to the area to prevent massive smuggling of rockets, missiles and weapons area we turn.

This is a significant challenge. I talked a lot about that with President Obama very seriously. I think he understands the challenge seriously this. I think we both are committed to try and find a realistic solution to this issue Achsahabetahon real first and foremost.

The second question is the question of legitimacy. I think the solution to the problem of legitimacy is that we recognize the Palestinian state as the state of nationality of the Palestinian people and they must recognize Israel as a Jewish nation. It is significant Locartam us. And the leadership to prepare their people and themselves to accept the idea that at last ended the conflict.

They make sure that the Palestinian state is a springboard for further conflict by other means, but it is the end of the conflict and the demands related to the conflict. For example, the two most prominent issues related to legitimize the end of conflict related to Palestinian refugees. Israel absorbs absorbing Jewish refugees since the war in 1948 all over the world. On the Palestinians to absorb the Palestinian refugees - in a Palestinian state.

Equally, there will be requirements to irredentism by Israel's Arab citizens. Their rights guaranteed individual rights. They guaranteed full civil equality in Israel, as already exists. And more demands will be a separate state in the Galilee, the Negev or autonomous regions.

In other words, solve this issue right now. When the president of the late Sadat of Egypt came to Jerusalem, he said: "At war, at spilling - Blood". We expect from President Mahmoud Abbas said: "The end of the conflict, the end of the claims, the end requirements. Israelis are ready to go very far. I'll lead them very far to bring peace. "

But for peace to be real peace - with security and an end to the conflict. These are the two pillars of peace and presented speeches at the bar - Ilan. It was just one of the things we did. We have removed many hundreds of roadblocks, checkpoints dirt roadblocks to facilitate the movement of Palestinian areas.

Type occurs in areas of Palestinian economic miracle. The Palestinian leadership has done important things there, but they were not helpful if we changed our policy. Can not exist a strong economy and growth in retail if you can - you can move goods and people. It's just impossible.

We we helped each other and we made these changes a - night. Not as a substitute for political peace, but as vicar. Economic peace which word is a supporter of a political peace.

The third thing we did was - in the words of Clinton's foreign minister - a move unprecedented. Unlike all previous governments, decided to freeze new settlement construction period of 10 months to encourage the Palestinians to open peace talks. So far, the past seven months. They did not.

Them to start conversations. They had to do it yesterday. They had to do it before 12 months, seven months ago. But we must not waste time.

While the privatization of the things we did, the Palestinians welcomed the report "Goldstone" International Court of Justice. They tried - without success, I am pleased to announce - to prevent our entry to the OECD. Despite these moves and other political pressures, Israel received the prestigious club. Yet not accepted to the G20, and it will take time. But Israel's entry into the OECD points to the strength of the Israeli economy.

Regarding the ongoing problems of incitement, we must not dwell on this issue. Palestinians are forbidden to stop us. I think the two of us seize the moment. This is a challenging and important and we have an opportunity to negotiate for peace.

We do not know how to change parts of the Middle East in the coming years. We do not know. We are facing a serious challenge in Iran, there is a shift in Turkey, Egypt now has stability. We take this opportunity to promote peace, and I'll do it.

There is a risk it. But that's what leaders do - they take risks. Ahazacartam the economy - I corrected a number of disabilities in the Israeli economy. Believe me, I took risks to do so. By the way, I was smart enough to do it at a young age that after such a move, loses the election, and if so we can return to work.

But coming back. There were only three people who returned to lead Israel again: one of them was David Ben - Gurion, Yitzhak Rabin was the second and third. When you get to my age advanced age, did not return to serve. It's not so much fun.

Returning to do something. I'm ready to do something and I am willing to take risks. No Asseachne our security, but I do take political risks. President Abbas to be willing to take risks. I know that President Obama will help us in this process. He enjoys believe in the Arab world - is important. This property could be used but we must begin the process.

We must stop all the delays, stop all the prerequisites, stop all the excuses and start now, in a week, in two weeks. Let's start the conversations that we start the talks without, somewhere - could be complete them.

People talk about the process that starts from the bottom comes up, but we talked about the economy and the political process from top to bottom. I believe, part of the equation is from top to bottom must be due to the crown. Only the leaders themselves can lead this process. Leaders may not only will the ceremonies at the end of the process.

Lycra is not using Chinonne dozens of committees or managing countless meetings. I think this is not particularly useful. I can tell you about my decision to change things inside Israel. Just have to move on and deal with any subject directly. There is no other way. Say again - last time - that's what we need to do now.

I know there is great skepticism. After 17 years, since the beginning of the Oslo process, skepticism certainly justified. But remember this moment Sadat came to Jerusalem. Remember that only a few years ago, Egypt and Israel waged a terrible war between them.

People underestimated Begin and they underestimated Sadat. They wrote countless articles skeptical. I intend to astonish the critics are skeptical. I have to share it. You - you can get on the trapeze and extend a hand without having a partner on the other side. It's essential.

It's one challenge we are facing, but I believe we are ready to deal with. I believe that the moment came to make the Israeli peace - a Palestinian wish and pray that our people bring tremendous benefit. Already see it partially in the West Bank even before a formal peace.

You can imagine many things that may happen in the region. Israel is a major economic engine, the source of creativity. I believe this is the most innovative society and economy in the world, and we can allow these forces - had done so within Israel. If we do this in our region, bring new life, new reality, our children, Palestinian children and to all peoples in the region who want to take part in this vision of peace.

But we are facing a different challenge and a great challenge, I'm talking about for many years. 14 years ago, when I came to the United States shortly after his election as prime minister for the first time I had the honor to address both houses of Congress. So I said the greatest danger the world faces is the threat of a nuclear Iran. Many raised an eyebrow at the time, now far fewer people are questioning. Today there is a broader and deeper understanding more about the dangers of a nuclear Iran. Hear of this understanding in Europe. Hear it in almost every private conversation that I or someone teams and senior manager with Arab leaders - almost without exception.

All of these leaders understand that a nuclear Iran is a threat not only to Israel. They understand that the biggest patron of terrorism get the most dangerous weapon - it would be a threat to the region and the world.

The problem with historical circumstance is to translate understanding into action. In fact, the problem in a large number of catastrophic historical periods had not been understanding. Understanding is a precondition for correct action. Of course once there is understanding, there is still a gap between what course think necessary and what is really doing.

I spoke with the White House last round of decisions of the UN Security Council against Iran, and also on the bill of the U.S. Congress signed by President Obama last week to introduce sanctions. UN sanctions are important because they convey to the Iranian regime that the international community led by President Obama, firmly oppose Iran's nuclear program. U.S. sanctions are important because they have teeth. As to trigger the strict imposition of sanctions and the more, the more they will be more teeth. I hope other countries, Europe and elsewhere, triggering harsh sanctions, especially those aimed at Iran's energy sector. This sector is vital for the existence of the regime.

I think not - you can be sure that these sanctions will stop Iran's nuclear program, so I appreciate the president's statement that Obama is determined to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons and that all options remained open.

In my opinion, to translate understanding into action control, we must answer the question whether the world can live with a nuclear Iran. Many influential people, and probably some people here today, no doubt a nuclear Iran is a threat, but think that maybe it's not a new threat. Let's not forget Slsobeittim had nuclear weapons. They were stopped. Therefore, several people claim to have nuclear Iran can also block.

But the Soviet Union was quite different from what we see today in Iran. No doubt Slsobeittim global ambitions and ideologies were, but in the international arena they were superior logic. Each time the Soviets faced a choice between their ideology and their survival, they chose survival. They did it in Berlin, Cuba - anywhere. To my knowledge, there were many Soviet suicide bombers.

 The Iranian regime is different. His motive acting out of a militant ideology based on entirely different values, the value system seems to be lacking in any sense but is very strong and well-being among people competing for the leadership of Muslim extremists.

 Look what happened a decade ago in another area of the world that militant. Taliban allowed Al - Qaeda, acting on his land, send terrorists to New - York to blow it and Washington. What were they thinking? Do they really thought the strongest power on earth Just ignore mass destruction cities? Do they really believe that the U.S. will ignore an attack on the financial center, on its military headquarters, the capital? Are they really so stupid? Or what they were not by common sense but by a violent beating extreme common sense?

 Iran sends children to the fields and mines. Iran denies the Holocaust. Iran openly calls to destroy Israel. Iran intensifies the Hezbollah with rockets and took control of half of Lebanon. Iran intensifies the Hamas with rockets and took control of Gaza and half the Palestinian government. Iran has sent terrorists terror into Egypt. Iran is sending arms into Yemen and Saudi Arabia threatens directly. Iran is sending weapons to South America. Iranians doing this today while still do not have nuclear weapons. Think what they'll do tomorrow when they have such weapons.

Very difficult for people to accept the lack of modern - makes sense. We tend to think that people and countries are driven by interests alone, by calculating the cost-benefit considerations. We recognize that people praise the mass death and send suicide bombers are not driven by complaints can be solved either by despair that can be easy for him.

We must recognize that the world believe that a jury, even believers are crazy. There are extremists who believe in faith twisted and are willing to pay any price to fulfill. They are driven by the Gaza hope they will succeed at any cost.

Shakespeare offers us see the method in the madness. But against militants in the Middle East are today's wide, we see the madness method - to recognize that there are people who are limited by the cost-benefit equation was still part of thinking about nuclear weapons. We must recognize that there are people, organizations and regimes behave in ways that no one acted accordingly since the beginning of the nuclear era that followed the Peace of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
